questions.question_text: A company needs to destroy several SSDs that contain sensitive information. Which of the following methods is BEST suited for the total destruction of the SSDs?

discussion.content:
I don't think it's an orthodox method, but incinerating the drive is the most correct answer.
SSDs do not store data magnetically like HDDs do, so degaussing may leave data intact. Overwriting or formatting the drive may still leave the drive in a recoverable state.
Even drilling or hammering a drive would be less than correct. Every component of the drive must be thoroughly destroyed, which is why incineration is the right answer. A high enough temperature will disrupt circuit paths and melt the chips within. An industrial mechanical shredder would also be a feasible destruction method. The drive manufacturer may offer their own solutions on their website.
Professor Messer states that Incinerating drives is the best way to ensure data, especially sensitive data is complete destroyed.

Selected Answer: C
Purifying fire!
Remember it says "Total Destruction", as in you aren't getting anything back. Other options only destroy, but you still have a physical unit.

comments.content: I agree "total destruction" would mean the physical drives are also gone which means incinerating is the best option.

discussion.content: OBJ-3.4: To solve an issue with a mobile application, you should normally attempt the following steps. First, clear the application cache since this locally stored information can become glitchy and cause an app to crash. If you have two of the same smartphones having the same issue, it is unlikely to be the application cache causing the issue. In this case, the technician would then attempt to update the OS of the smartphones. Updating the operating system can minimize compatibility issues and fix crashing applications. Third, you can try reinstalling the application if the other two options don't work.

Depends on the issue they're having with the app and what the app is.

It doesn't say whether or not they've ever had success running the app, where they got the app (through the Play Store or directly from some kind of enterprise link. It could be as simple as internet connectivity through a wifi isn't working that breaks the app, it could be a poorly designed app. 

It's questions like these that oversimplify how a real technician would handle the situation.

The correct answer would be E: Ask more questions to see what the real issue is. Anything else is simply throwing out solutions before you really know the problem.
